title: Durham (electoral district)
text:
Durham (formerly known as Clarington—Scugog—Uxbridge) is a federal <a href="Electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">electoral district</a> in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a>, Canada, that has been represented in the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> from 1904 to 1968 and since 1988.
Its first iteration was created in 1903 from <a href="Durham%20East">Durham East</a> and <a href="Durham%20West">Durham West</a> ridings. It consisted of the county of Durham. The electoral district was abolished in 1966 when it was merged into the <a href="Northumberland%E2%80%94Durham">Northumberland—Durham</a> riding. It was recreated in 1987 from parts of the <a href="Durham%E2%80%94Northumberland">Durham—Northumberland</a> and <a href="Ontario%20%28electoral%20district%29">Ontario</a> ridings.
The second incarnation of the riding initially consisted of the Town of Newcastle, the townships of Scugog and Uxbridge, <a href="Mississaugas%20of%20Scugog%20Island%20First%20Nation">Scugog Indian Reserve No. 34</a>, the part of the City of Oshawa lying north of Rossland Road, the allowance for road in front of lots 1, 2, 3 and 4, Concession 3 and part of the Town of Whitby lying north of Taunton Road.
In 1996, it was redefined to consist of the Township of Scugog, Scugog Indian Reserve No. 34, the <a href="Clarington">Town of Clarington</a> and part of the <a href="Oshawa">City of Oshawa</a> lying north of a line drawn from west to east along Taunton Road, south along Ritson Road North, east along Rossland Road East, south along Harmony Road North and east along King Street East.
The electoral district was abolished in 2003 when it was redistributed between Clarington—Scugog—Uxbridge, <a href="Oshawa%20%28electoral%20district%29">Oshawa</a> and <a href="Whitby%E2%80%94Oshawa">Whitby—Oshawa</a> ridings. Clarington—Scugog—Uxbridge was defined to consist of the townships of Uxbridge and Scugog, the Municipality of Clarington and the <a href="Mississaugas">Mississaugas</a> of Scugog Island reserve. In 2004, Clarington—Scugog—Uxbridge was renamed to its current name of Durham. Following the <a href="Canadian%20federal%20electoral%20redistribution%2C%202012">Canadian federal electoral redistribution of 2012</a>, the riding lost territory to <a href="Pickering%E2%80%94Uxbridge">Pickering—Uxbridge</a> and <a href="Northumberland%E2%80%94Peterborough%20South">Northumberland—Peterborough South</a> and gained territory from <a href="Oshawa%20%28electoral%20district%29">Oshawa</a> and <a href="Whitby%E2%80%94Oshawa">Whitby—Oshawa</a>. 
On August 24, 2020, Durham <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28Canada%29">MP</a> <a href="Erin%20O%27Toole">Erin O'Toole</a> won the <a href="2020%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada%20leadership%20election">Conservative Party leadership election</a> and was named <a href="Leader%20of%20the%20Official%20Opposition%20%28Canada%29">Leader of the Official Opposition</a>.
Demographics.
Ethnic groups (2006): 95.00% White, 1.52% Black, 1.24% Aboriginal
Languages (2016): 87.20% English, 1.56% French, 9.96% Non-official languages
Religions (2001): 52.26% Protestant, 24.13% Catholic, 2.97% Other Christian, 19.92% No religion
Median income (2015): $40,747
Members of Parliament.
This riding has elected the following <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">Members of Parliament</a>:
Current Member of Parliament.
This seat is currently held by <a href="Erin%20O%27Toole">Erin O'Toole</a> of the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada">Conservative Party of Canada</a>, who has also served as Leader of the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20of%20Canada">Conservative Party of Canada</a> since 2020. O'Toole, a former <a href="Captain%20%28Canadian%20army%20and%20air%20force%29">captain</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Canadian%20Air%20Force">Royal Canadian Air Force</a>, was first elected in the <a href="By-elections%20to%20the%2041st%20Canadian%20Parliament">2012 by-election</a>.
